Cool video.   You might have used a mildly acidic aqueous extraction in the beginning in order to remove the TEA.  I'm surprised you didn't get too much polymerization or even Michael additions into the enone.   One thing you can do to help avoid unwanted polymerizations is add a tiny bit of BHT (Butylated hydroxytoluene) to your distillation flask.  This is a radical inhibitor which can help suppress unwanted polymerization.   Finally, while IR is okay for fingerprinting the material, if you really want to get an idea of the purity, I would highly recommend NMR if you can find someone to run it for you!   Depending on the nature of future experiments, I could probably help you out there! :)

Part of that guitar scent is actually the wood used for the fretboard! African and Indian Rosewood have very distinctive smells, with the African variety being pleasant. So what about hot metal? I have washed metal with rubber gloves on and there is a distinctive smell that is the result of rinsing several times in around 165 degree F water. No skin contact and 4-5 rinses to ensure no soap residue. This was done for the purpose of dairy use stainless steel so these steps were mandatory.
Also when smelting metal or burning metal there are distinctive smells, as the metal gets to the "cherry" point it is definitely in an excited state and liable to be giving off vapors. And obviously when metals burn they are being transitioned to a gaseous state although I don't know what remains of the original element(s) once combusted there is at least for whatever aluminum alloy soda cans are made of a distinctive smell given off as they burn.
Then, also what about rust? there is definitely a "rusty" smell and anyone that has been around any significantly rusted metal can say that it definitely becomes airborne although not in a vapor form. are we smelling the resulting oxidized form of the metal? is that somehow reactive for humans?

If you're suicidal, take a shot every time he says 1-octen-3-one.

Also the precipitate you had was probably triphenylphosphine oxide. It's insolubility in many organic solvents is helpful in cleaning up Wittig reactions where it's a biproduct. I haven't ever tried it, but apparently you can isolate the triphenylphosphine oxide and reduce it back to triphenylphosphine to recycle it in future Wittigs.

Edit: The solid that crashed out of your resulting solution was probably more triphenylphosphine oxide. A lot of it will crash out on its own, but getting rid of all of it can be tricky without adding something like ZnCl2 or CuCl2 to complex with it. The Zn and Cu transition complexes that result are highly soluble in water and even more insoluble in organic media. Oh and also triethylammonium salts which can conveniently be removed in a similar fashion.

6:58 That seems like a pretty likely mechanism. Chloride is a good leaving group and phosphorous, in general, forms VERY strong bonds with oxygen atoms. The strength of P-O bonds drives one of the more interesting organic reactions they teach you in school: The Wittig reaction. Also side note, technically 1-octen-3-ol is pronounced "one octeen three all" as it stems from the IUPAC name octene.

A lot of heavy exercise with sweating for a prolonged time can give the skin a brass-like odour, especially if one does not wash for several days. I noticed that in my time in the army during field exercises. You can also get a whiff of it from homeless people who may have little access to washing or bathing.
The skin always has bacteria and other microbes on it. If you don't wash, the bacteria and dead skin and sweat accumulates. Of course some bacteria die, and they contain metals, like iron, and there are all sorts of chemical reactions going on, and some of these reactions create volatile, pungent chemicals.

I have an iron storage disorder in my blood, and at times I can smell (what I figured was my blood iron) my own blood, touched or not. It occurs when my blood iron as hemoglobin, ferritin and hematocrit get high as verified through blood tests. I can even "smell" if I'm bleeding as sometimes I don't clot well. It's really unambiguous. I can smell it in raw fresh cut beef. When I smell my hands after touching brass, there's a very strong smell, but it is nothing like what I'm calling the iron. All that said there are a bunch of things I can't smell that others can.

The inability to smell metal makes sense evolutionarily (for those who enjoy more biology than chemistry).
Pure metal virtually never exists in nature (certainly not in any amount to be useful evolution wise). Your nose simply never developed a sense for it.
Blood, for example, smells like “iron”. You arent smelling the iron in your blood though, you’re smelling the mixture of the blood (and the reactions produced as a result).

Hi. Perfumer here. This is probably my absolute favorite thing about perfumery, is the chemistry. Also how everyone interprets smells differently and we all have different experiences with scent. The brain pathway that interprets what you're smelling goes straight to the amygdala and hippocampus and directly links the fragrances to memories (IE the smell of fresh brewed coffee, fresh baked bread, the salty ocean). It's the strongest for of memory recall we have as humans. All of the fragrances i have made are based solely on memories and experiences i have had. I mean. Look. I've always found this "you can't really smell metal" Snapple fact to be kind of reductive and pointless, anyways. You never directly smell anything. You're basically always smelling some sort of specific part of something or a reaction of some chemical component of whatever it is you're smelling with something else, anyways. As in, when you smell cooking meat, you aren't really smelling that meat, you're only smelling parts of that meat that have been burned and oxidized or carbonized all to hell and thrown out into the air, but we don't say "you can't actually smell cooking meat, what you're actually smelling is [Chemical Compound] when it has reacted with burning fuel and oxygen!" When we start getting to this level of pedantry, then nothing is anything, anymore and describing anything becomes an exercise in pointless frustration.

I might have more of a chip on my shoulder than most about this because some know-it-all douchebag in highschool spent about 15 minutes being a know-it-all douchebag about this "fact" as if I was below stupid because I described something as smelling "metallic" to someone else.

Hi, thanks for your amazing work, you solved one of the questions that always bugged me. If you are looking for an idea for another video more or less related, I would really like to know what makes some people's sweat "corrosive" while others don't have this problem. I work in the manufacturing sector and many companies add in their recruitment procedure a sweat test (commonly touching a polished, clean steel sample) to avoir recruiting people that have a tendency to oxydize parts.
I for example can touch metal parts for months without leaving any oxydized fingerpring marks while my coworker has literally the most corrosive sweat I ever saw, if he touches a sample you can be sure that 48h later the part will be oxydized.
I think there might be different sources to investigate there, sweat salts concentration linked to the amount of water consumed and type of food consumed but also the tendency of a person to have a dry skin or sweat from their hands. At least that's what I have been guessing but it would be so cool if you could investigate the matter in a more scientific approach. Thanks a lot and continue the good work.

I read that metal "smells" because of dead microbes on their surfaces. Metal surfaces are variably antimicrobial (silver and copper being the most potent). Coins give off a strong smell because they're commonly handled and thus coated in dead microbes. It's also why surfaces recently treated with bleach smell gross for some time - you're smelling millions or billions of germs being ripped apart and releasing their innards.

I think the "clumsiness" at 7:40 was because the first time you poured in the oily octenol, a little bit dripped off the outer wall of the vial. I think this is definitely the reason why some metals smell; especially brass door handles, some cast keys,  and die cast metal objects.

I appreciate your doing the work to share this via video, not least because I've long wondered why handling imparts smells to coins, etc. (and fingers).

That said, although I'm confident that you're largely right in your conclusion (and you may well be entirely right), you may want to try pure tin before you close the book on this issue.

Tin certainly seems to have a characteristic scent, even when (to the best of my knowledge and belief) it is completely clean, and even at room temperature. When the metal is heated, the scent grows considerably stronger.

The scent of clean tin is considerably different from the scents (or stenches) that I perceive after handling other metals.

I can't rule out impurities in my tin, but I get the stuff from a reputable source, and the assay printout shows only tiny traces of impurities, all of which are other metals.
Now I no longer have to lay awake at night wondering why we could smell metal. Thanks!

You absolutely can smell metal. I used to grind metals and when there's metal dust in the air, I can tell you it is definitely something you can smell and it does not smell good. It smells about like how it tastes when it forms an electrochemical battery in your mouth. A nasty bitter similar to alkali taste. Imagine bitter taste mixed with ozone. That's pretty much it. Not going to market that as a perfume. You only think it has no smell since you haven't experienced a mechanism for it to reach your olfactory system, but oh, I have. You'll also likely experience the smell of zinc if you hit it with a propane torch, which I also have done. Zinc boils at a lower temperature than copper melts, by the way. Definitely a "do not try this at home" experiment.

Hey Nile Red, an idea for distilation, is do it by air drag. Since you have got a vaccuum pump, you can do it. It works for me in the lab when I have a high boiling point solvent and a product of reaction that can't be heated. This method consists in using 2 needles, one long and one short. The long one stays near the surface of the mixture, and connected to the air, the short one stays high in the flask and is connected to a trap that is connect then to the vaccuum pump. When you turn on the vaccuum, it will make a influx of air that will drag the solvent, just be sure to adjust the temperature and the flux so it doesn't drag the final product with it :)

Very simple test you can do to test this more thoroughly yourself. First of all, smell is actually just an extension of your sense of taste. They are even essentially the same sense, your nose just operates differently than your tongue. With that in mind, here's an at home experiment:

1. Take any kind of coin, doesn't matter what kind, although if your coin is made of copper it will effect the taste to some degree.

2. wash it off pretty reasonably thoroughly. This step does not need to be absolutely perfect, the water is to just help in the next step.

3. Dry it off with something like tissues or paper towels, ideally not a cloth because it could not be totally clean and it could leave behind a taste. Make sure you also have a pretty thick barrier between your skin and the coin while you're drying it off, several tissues or paper towels matted together for instance. You also want to make sure you're cleaning the coin thoroughly while drying it off, just to be absolutely certain the coin is totally clean. If you use soap, be extra super thorough doing this to be sure you remove all the soap otherwise it can affect the taste.

4. After it's dried off, remain not keeping any contact of the coin to your skin or other parts of your body.

5. Finally, just... Lick it. Lick the coin. You will notice it will have virtually no taste at all, again unless your coin is made of copper in which case there is a chance there will be a faint copper-y taste not unlike blood.

Wondering if have ever smelled aluminum that has been freshly machined (in a special way). It smells to me like a sulfur compound, slightly like hydrogen sulfide / rotten egg. The particular way to get this smell is to ream out a hole that is almost exactly the size of the reamer, with no coolant or lubricant, so that reamer rubs against the aluminum making this ultra-fine black film or "dust"   that adheres to the metals. I put "dust" in quotes because you can't disturb it by blowing on it, but you can wipe it off. (Also, to get this effect, it helps if the hole is not quite straight so that the reamer bends a bit. Can also sometimes get this smell by rubbing a fine stone on aluminum.)

You can smell metal. You can also identify different metals from each other by smell.
Yes what you are smelling is not just the metal, but rather its the reaction is has with other things in the environment.
This is the same with many things we smell. Nonetheless you can still use that smell to identify the material you are in front of, so id still call that "smelling metal".
The smell of metal isnt just "yourself", there are lots of things other than the oil from your skin that can react with the metal and give off the same smell.
You will smell the same thing if you are grinding/welding metals too, and each type gives off its own smell.
So yes you can smell metal, and no it isn't just yourself. Its the smell of the metal reacting with the environment.

- I have a hypersensitive sense of smell, and stainless steel even has a smell after being washed.
- Does smell change when handled right away versus being set aside for a week? A year? Unwrapping cutlery that's been on shelves unpurchased for a decade? Random cutlery kept loose in a box in an attic for a century?
- Does moisture matter to scent?
- Does air pressure matter to scent?

OK. Two things occurred to me when I saw your video.
1: You went to a lot of trouble to distill the stuff.
2: It made me consider colour perception...

To explain (thought experiment here):
>>> Describe the colour Blue to a blind man. <<<
Moving forward, we all know that the sky is blue. Sure about that? Shades of blue notwithstanding. But how do we perceive it? What I call blue may be perceived by your eyes as slightly greener (say) than how my brain interprets it.
Just maybe. Perhaps it is all merely subjective.
And so, as a corollary to our sense of colour, our sense of smell could conceivably be entirely subjective as well. Just maybe.
Your test/guests compared their sensations to what we may all agree upon as 'metallic' What is the yardstick?
In the printing industry, colours have a yardstick, and they are standardised by a system known as the Pantone Matching System (or PMS for short, whereby precise blends of Cyan, Magenta, Yellow and Black inks are mixed or formulated to create a tint which is perceived by humans as a recognisable, universally agreed-upon colour: 100% magenta and 100% yellow produce Red for example: I think it is known as PMS485).
Interestingly, a blind man could safely say that PMS485 is Red and be correct, according to the book or color chart. He would also be very handy in a darkroom, with respect I say, but I digress.
STOP!
Question is this: Now that the colour of Red can be so precisely mixed, how do we know that your perception of red is the same as mine? We agree on the formula yet our personal view of it may be 180 degrees in opposition without us knowing how to disagree. How can we be sure then that my sense of a metallic smell is the same as yours? We all may agree on it, based on our internal library of smell associations, but how can we be sure? How can we empirically standardrise it? After all, we have been told from birth that 'that smell is metallic' or 'that thing is red.'
Anyhow, your video triggered this thought-provoking string of ideas which I felt that I had to express. Sorry for waffling.
Over to you mate.

You pose some interesting points events in my life contradict.

I'm a machinist of long experience. My trade is making metal parts by removing chips using cutting tools mounted in rigid, powerful matchine tools. I remember puzzling over the scents my nose detected while running a planer. The example I'm advancing for consideration was a large thick steel plate being reduced in thickness to manufacture large drilling jigs. The cutting tool was high speed steel and I was cutting dry - ie, no cutting oil or other liquid. Hard tool steel cutting clean soft steel plate where the cutting tool geometry was carefully tuned for chip control and the table speed and incremental feed was optimized for efficient stock removal. A strong magnet mounted near the cutting tool accumulated no appreciable dust in a full 8 hour shift during which perhaps a half ton or more of metal was reduced to chips.

Bear in mind the surface being cut was freshly cut the previous step minutes before. So clean, fresh metal, little or no dust, no metal vapor - what was there to cause a detectable aroma? This has been a small mystery to me for 50 years.

I found the final thoughts at the end of the video interesting about smell and perception as it reminded me of a time in a lab were we had a whole closet full of highly concentrated oils of misc. aromas, including rose petals.

One thing I learned that no matter how nice a scent can be in some low concentration. When extremely concentrated they almost all stank terribly, even the rose scent.
We had also in the lab a small unit which allowed us to make spray cans. A friend used some smoke scent which is usually used in food articles to give them a fire wood smoked flavor and made a small, hand-sized spray of the flavor. Later in a class he used the spray on the bottom of the table of the teacher before a test.
as the test progressed we all got amused to see him sitting their and sniffing the air for that odd burned wood smell without being able to detect the source. He even asked us during the test if we could smell that burned wood scent and we all played innocent and said we couldn't smell anything.
After the test we explained the small joke to him and was amazed how easily our senses like smell and taste can be fooled.

Triphenylphosphine dichloride can be made from oxalyl chloride and triphenylphosphine oxide. It's actually a really good way of doing something useful with a phosphine oxide. I did this reaction with several substutited phenylphosphine oxides including, fluoro, chloro, pyridyl and methoxy. All substituents were para, and all were tri compounds. accepept pyridyl where only 1 phenyl was substituted.


Then kinetic study was carried out on each salt to see the activation energy required using the salts as convertin R-OH --> R-Cl
The results yielded te following...
Fluoro << Pyridyl < Chloro < Phenyl < Methoxy.
The latter 4 being pretty close in energy, however fluoro had a significantly lower activation energy (DCM solvent).

However when results were ran in a vacuum (as appose to in DCM), a significant change was observed. Only the donating groups were tested.
Chloro << Pyridyl < Fluoro

Molecular ion pair energy trends were as follows...
Chloro << Fluoro < Methoxy < Pyridyl < Phenyl
Again the latter 4 being pretty close, but chloro being significantly more stable.

Chloro's higher activation energy than fluoro came about because it also had a significantly lower transition state energy.


Edit: Also I've done this oxidation to using acetic anhydrideas the nucleophile, that might work in this scenario, saves using triphenylphosphine dichloride.

You'll like this. I used to restore antique Samurai Swords with traditional Waterstones. After a while you get to know what your stones smell like. Then you realize that each Sword has its own odor when you start handling them and scouring their surface and opening the Steel. Mind you that I buffered the H2O with Bicarbonate to minimize oxidation. Of course trace elements must have been partly responsible. Differences in smithing regions, Yamato, Yamashiro, Bizen, Soshu, and Mino being primary, and steel or ore supplies through the hundreds of years must be responsible for this.

Oh let me add this. I once did a Mutsu no Daijo Nagamichi Saku Katana for a client. About a year later another client sent me it's Twin. Not only did it respond to the stones the same, but smelled the same. I had it happen with a Mino den Katanakaji also. Who left his work Mumei or unsigned. I owned and restored one of its twins for my ex, and Immediately identified it as the same Swordsmth. This is why Japanese Sword Polishers or Togishi are referenced frequently to verify Swords and their Origins.
Just two examples of something most have never considered.

I am not a practicing chemist, however it occurs to me that maybe this stuff could be synthesized more quickly and with a potentially  higher yield.  Given that iron, copper, and zinc catalyze this reaction in a perhaps selective manner: take a piece of fine brass wool and fill a glass tube with it, use a constant current supply to gently heat the brass wool and use the slightly changing voltage across it to measure the temperature of the brass wool (reaction chamber).  Pull a partial vacuum on that with the remainder being wet air (you need a source of oxidation for the metal catalyzed reaction, use wet air?).  Use another glass tube and a magnet driven pump (stir bar with aerofoils on a bearing with a magnetic drive on the outside) to provide a flow of nitrogen through the reaction chamber (recirculating loop for the gas flow).  On the output end of the reaction chamber, add a cooled metal container (old cleaned out hardware store container of solvent) with more brass wool for cooling surface area as the receiving flask and a Peltier element and heat sink to provide it with fast cooling.  On the input end of the reaction chamber, spray in the pure 1-octen-3-ol, stoichiometric amounts of oxygen and water directly onto the brass wool.  With the proper temperature control, flow rate, and reaction vessel length; this may likely produce reasonably pure 1-octen-3-one with no hard to get reactants in a quick and scalable way.

My oxidation of choice is by using TEMP=O.BF4
Made from the reaction of TEMPO radical (stable and purchasable from sigma) with tetra fluoroboric acid and bleach (I used too much water in my first time making it and had to freeze dry it but you can recyst it.
Put that in DCM with your alcohol and some silica leave it for a bit, the yellow colour of the TEMP=O will dissapear and a white solid of TEMP-OH will form.
Once finished put you can pour the whole thing over a silica plug, and elute with a bit of DCM. The product will be clean straight of the silica plug. ~90% yields, product can be used immeiatly
The used up TEMP-OH can be extracted from the silica using warm water, neutralised with bicarb and turned back into the radical form by reaction with H2O2 (the colour change of white to red is easy to track. You can then make the TEMPO radical back into the active oxidising agent the same as before.

@NileRed There is another side to the "metallic smell". Many metals/alloys you encounter everyday, often steel or cast iron (or zamak) tend to be of lower quality or made from recycled, especially if they're dirt cheap items, or even the infamous "chinesium". What happens is that there's a small amount of slag or other dissolved impurities in said metal, due to manufacturing process. The amount of slag that can dissolve in metal is extremely small, but in industry since they work with kilotons of metal, the amount is not insignificant. When exposed to a strong acid or even just water corrosion, the metals tend to give off a phosphine-like smell, and I've noticed that every time I've done reactions involving iron nails, plates or wires, the smell was always present, even when I didn't touch the metal with my bare hands. The smell appears even when I used different acids (HCl, H2SO4, acetic acid, oxalic acid, phosphoric acid), but only or iron alloys. Neither copper, brass or aluminium gave that smell, although in a few isolated cases a few items made of zamak gave a similar smell (probably because it's usually made of recycled metals, so they don't always do quality control there). When I once dissolved some scrap metallic turnings from various metals, I also got that smell, but I'm not sure if it was because they had steel or some phosphorus containing copper/bronze. Unfortunately, I haven't tried dissolving higher purity alloys in acid to see if there's any difference between them and the lower quality common metallic alloys.

Have you considered metals that "fume" as the result of their reactivity? When steel is ground on a grinding wheel, it throws off sparks that are burning metal, and give off a characteristic odor that is (I presume) the result of the heating and oxides forming a dust. The same happens when torching steel. When vacuum tubes are broken open, the getter (vacuum deposited barium film on the inside of the glass) oxidizes and has the same odor, except more potent. Portland cement smalls similar as it is mixed in water. I would describe all of these as "alkaline" odors.
Astronauts describe the "smell of space" (after returning from a spacewalk) to be similar to "a torch on steel". The molecules (rarefied as they are) outside are whizzing by at speeds that correspond to hideous temperatures! These would be impacting metal structures of the station and involving them in all sorts of chemical reactions.
And need I mention osmium, named because of its odor, due to the formation of OsO4?

@17:05 These crystals are probably triphenylphosphine oxide as well. I do a lot of reactions with triphenylphosphine at work, which means I always get a lot of triphenylphosphine oxide as a by-product. This is quite difficult to remove from the actual products that I'm trying to make, but the best thing is indeed to remove as much DCM as possible, and extract the crude product with hexanes or petroleum ether. Even though much of the triphenylphosphine oxide is removed in this way, a small amount dissolves in the hexanes / petroleum ether and crystallizes out after removing these solvents. I always use column chromatography to get rid of the last traces of triphenylphosphine oxide.
By the way, the brown color of your product is probably also due to (some sort of "polymeric") triphenylphosphine oxide. When I'm working with this stuff I always get some sticky brown 'goo' after removing the DCM. What I always do is pouring a lot of petroleum ether on it and let it stir for a couple of days. After that most of the brown 'goo' is transformed into a yellowish white powder (crude triphenylphosphine oxide) which I remove by filtration.

Ok, to start of with, thanks for another entertaining video! Well, that metals and salts actually dont have a distinct smell is something I heard from my professor in first semester chemistry but we didnt dive this much into it explaining where the smell comes from. It was more or less a sidenote back then. Nice to see this topic picked up here by you now.
To be honest I think 1H-NMR is easyer to read than IR (plus its faster and give you possibly a full structure), but I do like that you added the IR data. I'd love to see this more in future videos. Considering how... messy... the purification was (maybe culumn chromatography would be faster, considering the different solubilitys its at least possible, thats for sure) I am really amazed how clean the IR was. There is clearly some alcohol still left (the OH-Bond is hard to overlook ;) ) but it loks quite well.
